page.title: 04Beef Farming - Farlesthorpe
page.content: The farmer owns Ivy House Farm in Farlesthorpe. His grandfather bought the farm in 1932 when it covered 35-40 acres. It has since been handed down through the generations and now it covers 83 acres. He is a mixed farmer but predominant in beef farming. He keeps pigs, bull beef and heifers. The bull beef are kept for 13-14 months and then sold. He also grows crops; peas (12 acres), cereals (33 acres), barley (15 acres). Most of the barley is used on the farm for feeding the intensive bull beef. The wheat is sent away for milling and eventual human consumption. The land is fertile but still needs improvement by fertilisers. He owns all his machinery and only needs to hire a combine harvester. Due to the intense mechanisation he does not employ anyone.
